name: Scanner, i940 desktop
description:
This unit process represents the gate-to-gate production of one Kodak Alaris model i940 desktop scanner (mass = 1.55 kg).  The system boundary includes: 1) the transport of raw materials to multiple manufacturing facilities where various subcomponents are produced; 2) the manufacture of subcomponents; 3) the transport of subcomponents to a different manufacturing plant for final assembly; 4) the assembly of subcomponents into a complete scanner; and 5) the transport of generated waste from the manufacturing facilities to a municipal solid waste landfill.  

The following processes and life cycle phases fall outside of the system boundary: 1) packaging of the completed scanner; 2) all transport downstream of the assembly plant gate; 3) sale of product; 4) product use phase; and 5) end-of-life phase (including recycling).

The use of this unit process for the analysis of similar devices requires professional judgement based on the degree of similarity.
category: 31-33: Manufacturing/3341: Computer and Peripheral Equipment Manufacturing

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Primary data is valid from 2015 - 2016.  Secondary data is valid from 2005 - 2016 (National Renewable Energy Laboratory 2016; Wernet et al. 2016).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data is representative of a global supply chain.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The manufacture of a desktop scanner that uses 2016 technology including information storage and processing and energy savings features.  The manufacture includes the manufacturing of subcomponents at other facilities and assembly at a central location.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
The system boundary includes: 1) the transport of raw materials to multiple manufacturing facilities where various subcomponents are produced; 2) the manufacture of subcomponents; 3) the transport of subcomponents to a different manufacturing plant for final assembly; 4) the assembly of subcomponents into a complete scanner; and 5) the transport of generated waste from the manufacturing facilities to a municipal solid waste landfill.  The following processes and life cycle phases fall outside of the system boundary: 1) packaging of the completed scanner; 2) all transport downstream of the assembly plant gate; 3) sale of product; 4) product use phase; and 5) end-of-life phase (including recycling).

DATA COLLECTION
For material inputs, data collection was based on scanner specifications provided by the manufacturer.  Other inputs (e.g. energy; waste transport and disposal) were calculated on the basis of quantity of input per kg of scanner produced.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
Uncertainty was estimated based on engineering judgment.  Material inputs had less uncertainty because they were based off of precise engineering specifications.  Other inputs  (e.g. energy; waste transport and disposal) had more uncertainty.

sources.name: Wood. (2016). Greenhouse Gas Life Cycle Assessment Summary Report - Kodak Alaris i710, i703EX, i940, i1150, i1150WN, i1190,i1190E, i1190WN Scanners, ISO 14044 Protocol
Institute for Environment and Sustainability. (2011). General guide for Life Cycle Assessment - Detailed guidance.
Wernet et al. (2016) The ecoinvent database version 3 (part I): overview and methodology.
National Renewable Energy Laboratory (2016). U.S. Life Cycle Inventory Database.

reviews.details: This dataset and its companion report (Wood 2016) were internally reviewed by Jay Mathewson of Kodak Alaris.

publication.name: Wood. (2016). Greenhouse Gas Life Cycle Assessment Summary Report - Kodak Alaris i710, i703EX, i940, i1150, i1150WN, i1190,i1190E, i1190WN Scanners, ISO 14044 Protocol

processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.
